A few things that would go a long way when it comes to reducing the frustration he causes, and making him a lot healthier as a champion would be:

- Increase the cooldown on his E in the early game by a respectable amount so people can react to him in the laningphase
- Remove the ''if at all possible, Yasuo's ultimate will place him outside of tower range'' bullshit, especially now that he's not building completely glass cannon
- Make it so he can only ult off his own knockup. Why?

> Unlike Assassins, Skirmishers aim to shred through any nearby enemy that approaches. **Because Skirmishers lack high-end burst damage or reliable ways of closing in on high-priority targets**, they are instead armed with situationally powerful defensive tools to survive in the fray, along with extreme sustained damage to cut down even the most durable targets.

the fact that allied abilities make his ultimate so reliable takes away a big weakness of a Skirmisher.

---

He'd probably get some compensation buffs, but I think it would do a lot of good in the long run

In eras long forgotten, {{champion:34}}  Frostbite used to proc the double damage from Nunu snowball and Ashe slow. They said "synergy was too good, nerf so only anivia can cause the proc"

Fast forward to the current season, Yasuo can get all the benefits of everyone else, despite getting everything else handed to him.

I'm playing Devil's Advocate here, but Yasou doesn't even have access to his own ult, unlike Anivia's Frostbite which she always has access to, but only gets the bonus effect IF she gets the Frozen debuff. Anivia has two ways of applying her own debuff, Yasou only has one, and MAYBE more if his team comp is agreeable (and we all know that those who play Yasou could care less about Team Comps)

anivia nevers uses her E without a frost effect
never is a big word but basically 98% of the time she will wait her ulti/Q 

and with the new patch her gameplay even changed more, now she uses ulti W to keep you in ulti and then E
never saw an anivia using her E without a frost effect
But she can still use it regardless. Sure, it ain't the best choice, but it still does decent damage and can secure a last minute trade.

sure, let yasuo uses his ulti without knock ups, while making it doing 1/2 of the damage, duration of knock up reduced by 1/2, and armor penetration is reduced by 1/2

no yasuo player will use it without a knock up
Kind of defeats the purpose though. Theres a huge difference between 'Use when ideal' and 'Can't use unless'. Yasuo's ult is strong because it has a unique limiter.

Anivia E is on a short CD, and has TWO ways to proc it in her kit, one is basically impossible to miss. (A little hard now, since the change but still so)

Yasuo Q has a much longer CD then Anivia Q/Ult together and it also needs to be stackup up, which means you need to prepare before a fight starts to get the most use.

Anivia's E does the damage of a normal ability if she uses it normally. However, it can deal twice the damage of a normal ability if the condition is hit. If you use Anivia as an example, Yasuo's ult should deal average damage on the ult PER PERSON (Which his damage is already pretty low compared to others) and double otherwise.

Another thing, Anivia is safe when she uses her E, Yasuo is in danger when he ults.

I think you mean Anivia's ult/e, since Anivia's Q alone has the same cooldown as three of Yasuo's Qs at rank 1(which she generally keeps until level8) and that's before he gets attack speed to lower it further, which he will get far sooner than Anivia will get CDR.)

As for "danger", I think Yasuo's massive shield (especially late-game) makes him much safer than he appears.

Making him only able to ult off of actual knockups (seriously, how does he ult off of stuff like vayne E?) instead of all forms of displacement would encourage synergy picks and thought instead of him simply mashing R any time an ally hard CCs someone.

It would make sense if it only worked off of specific abilities that visibly knock a champion a good distance off the ground for more than 0.125 seconds: {{champion:40}} {{champion:267}} {{champion:163}} {{champion:12}} {{champion:201}} {{champion:54}} , but not stuff like {{champion:254}} {{champion:57}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:412}} {{champion:18}}

What's broken should be nerfed.
What's unhealthy should be reworked.

For example, a passive on champ that is supposed to be strong early that gives him nearly 0 significant effect early, but becomes of broken proportions (1k Health shield, 1k true damage) very late into game is not literally broken, since it does have the weak window. But factors that the champ shouldn't be strong lategame as well AND that the passive is useless to you unless enemies give you lategame make it unhealthy (feast or famine).

A nerf to such passive would make it even more irrelevant early game and fine lategame. A rework might change it or replace it to make the champion overall more healthy, so that they aren't strong or weak.

Shouldn't it be "what's overly strong should be nerfed, what's broken should be fixed, what's unhealthy should be reworked?"

Because broken better implied something that just doesn't work the way it's supposed to. Like, say, a ratio being ten times as powerful as it should be because someone forgot a zero in a single part of the code.
That's a bug really.
Yes, a something that's broken is bugged. That's the point I was making.

Well, the word itself, however, is not used in that context much on Boards.
When they discovered the weird interaction of Riven dashield and CC displacement, most people I saw weren't talking much about her being broken. They however do say that If she does more damage than they think she should, however as part of intended number.

A rework would give him a more healthy kit which can be easier to tweak. Right now if you tweak anything on Yasuo he becomes incredibly overbearing or underwhelming. (The latter hasn't really happened yet.)
